journal-title-group.journal-title: bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology

title-group.article-title: Mechanical imbalance between normal and cancer cells drives epithelial defence against cancer

article-meta.aff: 1Tata Institute of Fundamental Research Hyderabad (TIFR-H), Hyderabad 500046, India
2Department of Physics, Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, USA
3Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering, Harvard University, Boston, MA 02115. USA
4Max Planck Institute for Medical Research, Heidelberg 69120, Germany

author-notes.corresp: *All correspondence related to theory and experiments should be addressed to D.B. (d.bi@northeastern.edu) and T.D. (tdas@tifrh.res.in), respectively.

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: Cell competition enables normal wildtype cells of epithelial tissue to eliminate mutant cells expressing activated oncoproteins such as HRasV12. However, the driving force behind this fundamental form of epithelial defence against cancer remains enigmatic. Here, we employ tissue stress microscopy, theoretical modelling, and a new collective compressibility measurement technique called gel compression microscopy to unveil the mechanism governing competition. Stress microscopy reveals unique compressive stress experienced by the mutant cells, contrasting with predominantly tensile stress experienced by normal cells. A cell-based computer simulation of the process then predicts that this compressive stress arises out of a mechanical imbalance between two competing populations due to a difference in their collective compressibility and rigidity. Gel compression microscopy then empirically confirms that the mutant population is three times more compressible than the normal population. Mechanistically, this difference stems from the lower abundance and coupling of junctional E-cadherin in the mutant cells, which weakens cell-cell adhesions, rendering the mutant population more compressible. Taken together, our study elucidates the physical principle and underlying molecular mechanism driving cell competition in epithelial defence against cancer, opening new directions for mechanomedicine.

body.p: Epithelial defence against cancer (EDAC) is a non-cell autonomous removal of transformed mutant cells expressing constitutively active forms of oncoproteins such as HRasV12 1-4. It belongs to a broad class of non-cell autonomous cell elimination processes called cell competition, which, besides EDAC, controls organ development, tissue quality control, and ageing5,6. During EDAC, normal epithelial cells eliminate transformed mutant cells from the tissue by apical extrusion or by basal delamination3. Despite some recent progress, the mechanisms underlying how normal cells recognize and eliminate the mutant cells remain largely elusive1. The competitive removal of mutant cells requires extensive reorganization of force-bearing cytoskeletal elements in the surrounding normal cells, particularly at the interface between normal and mutant cells7–9. The process additionally depends on the mechanics of the extracellular matrix10, indicating possible modulations of cellular mechanical forces during EDAC9,11–14.

Mechanical forces play critical roles during cell competition in general9,11. A differential in cell proliferation potential between two competing populations can drive out the population with a lower proliferation potential by compaction. Also, cells carrying distinct genetic lesions can have varying sensitivities to compaction, which might lead to their elimination9. This explains how a fast-growing population bearing higher resistance to deformation and elimination can have a competitive advantage over a slow-growing population12,13,15,16. However, it is not clear how cell elimination occurs when the proliferative differential is trivial. For example, the competitive elimination of epithelial cells expressing oncoprotein HRasV12 by normal wildtype epithelial cells is well-established in a model for EDAC3,4,10, but whether it arises from a growth differential is not understood. We probed the growth potential of these populations by quantitating their number expansion in time, starting from a similar number density (Supplementary Figs. 1a-b) or by directly measuring the proliferation rate using ethynyl deoxyuridine (EdU) labeling (Supplementary Figs. 1c-d). These experiments revealed that the difference in growth potential between mutant and wildtype populations is not significant. In fact, HRasV12-expressing mutant cells show slightly higher proliferation post-48 hours of growth. Thus, in this model for EDAC, despite having a slightly higher growth rate, the mutant cells are eliminated during competition with normal cells. The mechanisms underlying this competitive elimination of the transformed cells by normal cells remain poorly understood. While it is possible that tissue and cell mechanics might play a crucial role here, in the absence of direct measurement of forces during EDAC, it is unclear how tissue mechanics regulates non-proliferative cell competition between the wildtype and mutant cells.

sec.title: Competition-induced compression of the mutant population
sec.p: To this end, we measured tissue forces in a model for cell competition, in which we utilized the competition between wildtype Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) and HRasV12-expressing mutant MDCK epithelial cells3. In this model, the expression of HRasV12 is dependent on the Tet-on system and is induced by a tetracycline derivative called doxycycline, enabling us to trigger cell-cell competition at will. We mixed wildtype and HRasV12-expressing mutant cells in a 40:1 ratio (Supplementary Fig. 2a) so that in the absence of doxycycline, mutant cells would form small colonies (two-ten cells, Fig. 1a and Supplementary Fig. 2b), surrounded by wildtype cells. We then exposed this heterogeneous epithelial monolayer to a medium containing doxycycline, which induced HRasV12 expression in the mutant cells (Fig. 1a). This monolayer system thus mimicked an in vivo scenario where mutant cells appear in a normal tissue background3,17. Importantly, we employed 4 kPa polyacrylamide gels as substrate for this model to mimic physiological stiffness10. Subsequently, mutant cells were extruded out of the monolayer (Supplementary Fig. 2b). However, we did not observe such extrusion in the homogenous HRasV12-expressing monolayer (Supplementary Fig. 2g). Only when these mutant cells interfaced wildtype cells in their vicinity, an active remodeling of the actomyosin occurred towards the mutant-wildtype interface, as highlighted by distinct phosphorylated myosin II light chain (pMLC2, active form of myosin II motor18) surrounding mutant cells (Supplementary Fig. 2c). These results indicated that the extrusion of the HRasV12-expressing cells from the heterogeneous monolayer is a non-cell autonomous process and requires physical contact between the two populations.

Next, to elucidate the change in the mechanical force field during cell competition, we combined traction force microscopy with Bayesian inverse stress microscopy19 (Supplementary Fig. 2d). We also used Bayesian force inference20 (Supplementary Fig. 2e) in another independent set of experiments. From traction force microscopy experiments, we observed that upon induction of HRasV12-expression, traction forces increased along the interface between normal and transformed mutant populations (Fig. 1b and Supplementary Fig. 2h). Simultaneously, stress microscopy revealed local compressive stress appearing in the regions occupied by mutant cells (Fig. 1c and Supplementary Fig. 2h). We concluded that this compressive stress is a unique mechanical signature of cell competition since in a homogeneous population of either normal or mutant cells, stresses remained predominantly tensile (Supplementary Fig. 2f-g), as reported previously19,21,22. While the complete extrusion of mutant cells took at least six hours after the doxycycline exposure (Fig. 1a and Supplementary Fig. 2h), compressive stresses arose around two hours post-doxycycline exposure (Supplementary Fig. 2h), indicating that compressive stress precedes cell rounding up and extrusion. In addition, compressive stress appeared to be restricted only to mutant cells as the background tissue comprising normal cells presented a predominantly tensile stress field (Supplementary Fig. 2f-g). To capture the cellular-level effect of the coarse-grained compressive stress obtained from the stress microscopy, we then used Bayesian force inference to compute the relative intracellular pressure and relative interfacial tension at the cellular scale (Figs. 1d-f). This analysis revealed lower interfacial tension (Fig. 1d) and higher intracellular pressure (Fig. 1e-f) in transformed mutant cells as compared to surrounding normal cells at the time when multicellular compressive stress appeared. Together these experiments revealed that while epithelial tissues are generally tensile systems, during the competition between normal and mutant cells, compressive stress arises. This compressive stress precedes the extrusion of transformed mutant cells and is a unique mechanical signature of cell competition.

sec.title: Distinct characteristics of mutant cells
sec.p: To understand why mutant cell-colonies experience compressive stress specifically during competition with the wildtype cells, we proposed a physical modelling of a tissue containing heterogeneous mixture of mutant and wildtype cells using the Self-Propelled Voronoi model. However, accurately capturing this heterogeneity requires an understanding of the key differential attributes between the wildtype and mutant populations. These characteristics include homeostatic density, which is the peak density of a confluent monolayer at which the cell division rate becomes negligible, and the integrity of cell-cell junctions.

We first looked at the homeostatic density of these two populations since a differential in homeostatic densities alone can dictate the outcome of two competing populations24. To this end, we first quantified homeostatic cell areas within homogeneous confluent monolayers of normal or mutant cells and found that HRasV12-expressing mutant cells exhibit higher homeostatic cell areas than wildtype cells. However, during competition, in the presence of wildtype cells, HRasV12-expressing mutant cells got significantly compacted (Supplementary Fig. 3a). We estimated the competition-associated compaction relative to the homeostatic density by calculating relative compaction as Δρ = (ρc – ρh)/ ρh (Supplementary Fig. 3b, Eq. SI-6). We then hypothesized that this compaction could be a consequence of compressive stress and hence, compaction should increase within the increasing compressive stress. To test this hypothesis, we varied the concentration of doxycycline, which led to different levels of HRasV12-expression (Supplementary Fig. 3b). Consequently, the compressive stress also changed, increasing with increasing doxycycline concentration (Supplementary Fig. 3b). Next, plotting the relative compaction with the maximum compressive stress obtained for HRasV12-expressing colonies revealed a nearly linear relationship between the compressive stress and the relative compaction (Supplementary Fig. 3b), indicating a critical consequence of compressive stress on competition-associated compaction of the mutant cells.

We next looked at the integrity of cell-cell junctions in normal and transformed mutant cells. Here we characterized homotypic cell-cell adhesions by immunostaining junctional markers including E-cadherin and alpha-catenin. We found that in the mutant cells, E-cadherin was localized to cell-cell junctions as well as it showed vesicular distribution within the cytoplasm (Supplementary Fig. 3e-f). This cytoplasmic vesicular E-cadherin pool was not observed in the wildtype cells (Supplementary Fig. 3c-d), indicating an instability in cell-cell junctions in the mutant cells. We further corroborated this observation by performing super-resolution spinning-disk confocal microscopy using optical photon reassignment (SoRa)23 with E-cadherin (stained by an antibody) to show that junctional E-cadherin was significantly deteriorated in the mutant cells as compared to the junctions of wildtype cells (Supplementary Fig. 3g). Alongside, alpha-catenin in mutant cells showed a distinct cytoplasmic distribution pattern owing to the reduction in mature adherens junctions. This result reaffirmed the fact that cell-cell junctions were compromised in the mutant cells (Supplementary Figs. 4a-d). Furthermore, live-cell imaging of junctional membranes in a monolayer of mutant cells displayed remarkably dynamic and continuous short-time-scale ruffling whilst junctional membranes in wildtype cells were stable at such short timescales and did not show this peculiar phenotype (Supplementary Figs. 4e-g). These results revealed instability in cell-cell junctions specifically in the mutant cells, while the normal cells showed relatively stable cell-cell adhesions. Surprisingly, we did not observe any significant difference in cell-matrix adhesions, as marked by endogenous paxillin in the two cell types (Supplementary Figs. 4h-j). Taken together, these results elucidated the characteristic differences between the wildtype and mutant cell populations, which we subsequently feed into our computational model.

sec.title: The computational Self-Propelled Voronoi model explains the origin of compressive stress
sec.p: To gain deeper understanding of the emergent mechanics resulting from competition, we used a well-known physical model for confluent tissue, the Self-Propelled Voronoi model (SPV) 24–27, to simulate a heterogeneous monolayer. In this model, the heterogeneities in cell types were represented by differences in the single cell-level mechanical parameters that governed each cell (details of the model are outlined in the SI text). These parameters include the single-cell area and perimeter elastic moduli KA and KP, and homeostatic preferred cell area and perimeter A0 and P0 respectively. We simulated a co-culture of two types of cells in the SPV, in which a circular island of mutant cells (M) was surrounded by wildtype cells (WT) (Fig. 1g). In this study, we specifically investigated the emergent behavior when these properties differed between mutant and wildtype cells, focusing on the differences in KA, A0, and P0 values. In our simulations we therefore set KP = 1 for all cells and use A0WT as the unit of length. Therefore, the sum total nondimensionalized mechanical energy function for the cell layer (derived from Eq. SI-1 in SI Section F1) is given by: (1)E=∑i∈MTcells(Ai−1)2+(Pi−P0WT)2+∑i∈Mcellsk(Ai−A0M)2+(Pi−P0M)2 where we have defined the ratio of cell area elasticities k=KAM/KAWT.

Based on our experimental findings that wildtype cells maintained their cell-cell junctions and established a durable, quiescent epithelial layer under ordinary circumstances (Supplementary Fig. 3c-d,g and Supplementary Fig. 4a-b,e-j), we assigned a P0WT value of 3.65 to these cells, which corresponded generically to a rigid jammed cells28–30. Simultaneously, the observation from experiments that HRasV12-expressing cells exhibited less stable cell-cell junctions than wildtype cells (Supplementary Fig. 3e-g and Supplementary Fig. c-j) implies that the mutant cells should have a larger value of P0, corresponding to a softer unjammed cell. Furthermore, the larger homeostatic regions observed in mutant cells (Supplementary Fig. 3a) implied a larger value of A0. Taken together, we propose that the competition of cellular junctional properties between M and WT cells can be encoded by a dimensionless cell shape index (q0=P0/A0). We first investigated the mechanical properties of the model cell layer by computing the hydrostatic pressure (Π) and interaction normal stress (σn) for the mutant and wildtype populations and the mechanical tension (Tij) at cell-cell junctions31 (Eq. SI-3-5 in SI Section F1). We observed that regardless of the size of the circular island, mutant cells exhibited lower junctional tension than wildtype cells when q0M>q0WT (Fig. 1g and Supplementary Fig. 5a). Meanwhile, mutant cells experienced higher homeostatic pressure than wildtype cells when A0M>A0WT and P0M>P0WT (Fig. 1h). Further, we found that wildtype cells exerted compressive stress on mutant cells (σM < σWT) (Supplementary Fig. 5b), with the stress gradient consistently oriented from high in wildtype cells to low in mutant cells. These phenotypic differences at the individual cell level provide the wildtype cells with a significant advantage in exerting compressive stress on the mutant population.

Consistent with the findings from our experiments (Supplementary Fig. 3a-b), the model was able to accurately capture the density compaction observed in the transformed population within a competitive environment. Specifically, using the same compaction parameter Δρ (Eq. SI-6 in SI Section F2), which exhibited positive values when the mutant cells were under compressive stress or elevated pressure (Fig. 1i), the simulations revealed an interesting finding that the increased compaction observed in the transformed population is primarily influenced by the ratio of the single cell area elasticities k=KAM/KAWT (Fig. 1j). To quantify the effect, we calculated the compressibility, C = ∂Δρ/∂Π (carried out in the linear response regime, see SI Section F2 for details). From the results shown in Fig 1j, we observed that when is k < 1, the mutant cells exhibit greater compressibility compared to the wildtype cells, whereas for k > 1, the compressibility of the wildtype cells exceeds that of the mutant cells. This provides compelling evidence for the crucial role of the elastic properties of tissue in determining its susceptibility to EDAC, which originates from mechanical imbalances at the microscopic cellular level.

sec.title: Gel compression microscopy (GCM) to measure collective compressibility
sec.p: We then assessed whether the wildtype and mutant populations indeed differed in compressibility, as predicted by our theoretical modelling. To be able to reliably measure collective compressibility, we invented a novel biophysical technique termed as Gel Compression Microscopy (Fig. 2a-b and Supplementary Fig. 6a-b; for details see methods). Existing methods to study epithelial tissue mechanics rely either on atomic force microscopy-based indentation32,33, which only measures individual cell cortical stiffness but fails to sample bulk tissue mechanical properties, or on free-hanging monolayer compression, which requires cell-cell junction fidelity to sustain a suspending a monolayer of cells34,35. As we have observed previously, HRasV12-expressing cells have weak cell-cell junctions. Hence, we ruled out the free-hanging monolayer setup. Therefore, we were motivated to devise a unique technique where one can live-image a compressing monolayer of cells in real-time (Fig. 2b) and quantitate its compressibility at the multicellular scale (Fig. 2e), while the given monolayer rests on a physiologically relevant substrate (Supplementary Fig. 6a-b). The gel compression microscopy set-up consists of a cell growth-conducive polyacrylamide hydrogel of defined stiffness interfacing with an acrylic acid-based pH-responsive hydrogel (Supplementary Fig. 6a)36. The pH-responsive hydrogel expands at a buffer pH above 6 and contracts at a buffer pH below 4. For better control of the separation between the polyacrylamide gel and the pH-responsive gel and for reproducibility, we utilized soft lithography53 (Fig. 2a and Supplementary Fig. 6b). Next, to carry out compressibility measurements, we cultured the wildtype or HRasV12-expressing mutant cells to confluency on top of the polyacrylamide gel and subsequently immerse the interfacing pH-responsive gel with normal growth medium (pH ∼ 7.4) (Supplementary Fig. 6a). Henceforth, the pH-responsive gel expands at a constant rate exerting a constant multicell-scale compressive stress on the wildtype or HRasV12-expressing monolayer grown over the polyacrylamide gel (Fig. 2d). We computed the relative compressibility of the mutant monolayer relative to that of the wildtype monolayer (Figs. 2c and 2e). In our initial experiments, we used the polyacrylamide gel with the Young’s modulus of 4 kPa, which is a physiologically relevant tissue stiffness10. On 4 kPa gel, the wildtype cell monolayer showed a significant and distinctly lower compressibility modulus relative to gel alone (Fig. 2f). In contrast, the mutant cell monolayer showed no difference in compressibility as compared to the gel-alone control (Fig. 2f). We then wondered whether mutant cells possess a distinct but relatively much smaller compressibility modulus than a 4 kPa gel. To this end, we performed the compressibility experiments with a softer polyacrylamide gel with a Young’s modulus of 0.87 kPa (Fig. 2g). Here, we found that the transformed mutant monolayer showed a compressibility modulus which was comparable to this soft gel but orders of magnitude higher than the wildtype monolayer (Fig. 2h). Taken together, as had been predicted by our simulations (Fig. 1j), the compressibility measurements with gel compression microscopy suggested that there exists a distinctively higher collective compressibility of the mutant population as compared to their wildtype counterpart and that in line with our predictions, forms the basis of competition driven compressive stress during epithelial defense against cancer.

sec.title: Different regimes of mechanical phenotypes in cell competition
sec.p: Our experiments on active compression revealed that the transformed mutant cells exhibit higher bulk tissue compressibility than their wildtype counterparts (Fig. 2f, h), consistent with our previous linear-response measurements (Fig. 1j). This difference in collective tissue elasticity between the competing populations represents a key mechanical cue driving non-proliferative cell competition in events such as EDAC. To further understand the underlying factors that contribute to this competition, we incorporated active compression into the SPV. This was achieved by allowing the wildtype cells to exert an active self-propelled force on the mutant island (Eq. SI-7,8, see SI Section F3 for a detailed discussion), thereby generating collective elastic response. When an active force was applied, the mutant cells experienced compression. By quantifying the relative change in the total area occupied by the mutant cells, we derived the compressive areal strain using Eq. SI-9. This enabled us to calculate the bulk modulus B (Eq. SI-10), which represents the material’s response to isotropic compressions (also done in the linear response regime, see SI Section F3 for a detailed discussion). In essence, the bulk modulus of a material is inversely related to its compressibility. We measured B for a small magnitude of the active force (see SI Section F3) and a wide range of values of k, A0M and δq0=q0M−q0WT with q0WT=3.65 as reported in the SPV modelling section of this work. Fig. 3a illustrates that the differential bulk modulus (ΔB = BM − BWT) between wildtype and mutant cells are controlled by both k and δq0. Notably, ΔB increases linearly with k A0M, where the slope is independent of δq0 (Fig. 3b). After subtracting by an offset that depends on δq0, the data collapsed (Fig. 3b inset, see SI Section F3 for details) to a simpler functional relationship between ΔB,kA0M and δq0, given by:

(2)ΔB−bδq0=f(kA0M) These results indicate that competition in cell area elasticity plays a central role in driving the differences in bulk modulus between M and WT cells. Conversely, the parameter δq0, which represents competition in cellular junctional properties, exerts a more subordinate influence.

While the bulk modulus provides insights into a tissue’s mechanical response to isotropic compression, the shear modulus is essential for evaluating the tissue’s reaction to shear forces. Notably, both solid and fluid materials possess a bulk modulus, whereas the shear modulus is a characteristic exclusive to solids. As a material transitions from a solid state to a flow state, its shear modulus diminishes to zero. Here instead of calculating the shear modulus explicitly for M and WT colonies, we used the mean edge tension (Eq. SI-11) as an approximation for the shear modulus (see SI Section F3 for details). Previous research has demonstrated a linear relation between these two quantities37.

In Fig. 3c-d, we observe that the differential tension (Δτ = τM − τWT) decreases as δq0 increases, this occurs for all values of k, which only sets the rate of decrease. Fig. 3d inset demonstrates that the functional relationship between Δτ, δq0, and k for A0M=1 exhibits a universal scaling collapse (see SI Section F3 for details) described by: (3)Δτ=kdf(δq0) These results indicate that the competition in cellular junctional properties (δq0) plays a central role in driving the differences in shear modulus between M and WT cells. Conversely, competition in cell area elasticity (k) exerts a more secondary influence.

Our simulations show that, in addition to differences in homeostatic cell area (A0), cells can compete via differences in their area elasticity (k) and junctional properties (δq0). Taken together, in Fig. 3e we propose a phase diagram that identifies four possible regimes of mechanical competition (see SI Section F3 for details). Given that transformed cells exhibit weaker cellular junctions than their wild-type counterparts, our theoretical model predicts a reduced shear modulus for these cells. Simultaneously, their increased compressibility results in lower cell area elasticity, leading to a diminished bulk modulus compared to WT cells. These findings lead to the conjecture that successful EDAC requires the competing populations to emerge as winners in Region II and losers in Region IV (shaded red in Fig. 3e) of this mechano-phenotypic phase diagram.

sec.title: Role of destabilized cell-cell junctions of mutant cells
sec.p: Finally, we attempted to understand the mechanistic basis for this difference in collective compressibility between the mutant and normal cell populations. At the single-cell level, atomic force microscopy experiments have delineated that HRasV12-expressing mutant cells are stiffer than wildtype cells when in an adherent state whilst they are softer when in loosely attached or suspended form32,33,38. In contrast, we found higher collective compressibility in mutant cells. One possible explanation for these two apparently discrepant observations is the weaker cell-cell adhesions in the mutant cells as compared to the wildtype cells. Indeed, junctional E-cadherin mislocalization leading up to weaker cell-cell adhesions, upon Ras transformation, has been shown before39. Therefore, it is possible that weak cell-cell adhesions make a collective of mutant cells more compressible than a collective of wildtype cells. Relevantly, it is known that a matrix metalloproteinase-dependent cleavage of the extracellular domain of the cell-cell adhesion protein E-cadherin drives epithelial extrusion40. We, therefore, hypothesized that cell-cell adhesions in the HRasV12-expressing mutants could be compromised due to the cleavage of the extracellular domain of E-cadherin. To test this hypothesis, we used DECMA-1 antibody which binds to the extracellular domain of E-cadherin. Upon mild detergent pretreatment, which permeabilizes cell membrane as well as partially disrupts the interaction between two E-cadherin molecules from the adjacent cells, DECMA-1 detects both cytoplasmic and membrane-bound E-cadherin, provided their extracellular domains are intact. Without the detergent, DECMA-1 detects only those E-cadherin molecules that are not bound to other E-cadherin molecules and have their extracellular domains intact. We stained both wildtype and mutant cells with this antibody with or without the detergent pretreatment. With detergent pretreatment, we found that E-cadherin remains intact at the junctions of the mutant cells and wildtype cells (Fig. 4a). However, without membrane permeabilization, DECMA-1 showed staining only at the junctions of the mutant cells (Fig. 4b). These results revealed that E-cadherin molecules in mutants remains intact but not bound to E-cadherin molecules of the adjacent cells. To understand the reason behind the improper E-cadherin coupling, we then studied the dynamics of E-cadherin in live cells expressing a E-cadherin-GFP construct. We observed an enhanced transport of E-cadherin in mutant cells but not in wildtype cells (Fig. 4c), where E-cadherin molecules showed distinct vesicular fingerprints. Interestingly, this enhanced transport was not due to the endocytic awakening41 since none of the endocytic compartments, including Rab5 for early endosomes, Rab11 for recycling endosomes, Rab7 for late endosomes and LAMP1 for lysosomes, showed any preferential co-localization with E-cadherin in mutant cells (Supplementary Figs. 7a-e).

In addition, using SoRa super-resolution imaging, we had found that junctional E-cadherin was significantly deteriorated in the junctions of mutant cells (Supplementary Fig. 3g). To recover the junctional E-cadherin pool in the mutant cells, we overexpressed E-cadherin-GFP in mutant cells. We assumed that E-cadherin overexpression would lead to the recovery of junctional E-cadherin concentration, and because of increased concentration, it would also lead to enhanced coupling of E-cadherin molecules, effectively “gluing” the mutant cells. Super-resolution imaging with SoRa revealed that junctional E-cadherin pool was indeed recovered within wildtype range upon E-cadherin overexpression (Fig. 4d). Further, when we performed traction force microscopy coupled with stress microscopy in the competition setup with wildtype cells and these E-cadherin-GFP overexpressing cells, there appeared to be no compressive stress at the mutant loci (Fig. 4e) unlike what we had observed before with the mutants alone (Fig. 1c). In fact, just by enriching junctional E-cadherin pool, we could rescue the competition dependent compressive stress which the mutants would experience otherwise, when surrounded by wildtype cells (Fig. 4e). Finally, we performed gel compression microscopy to evaluate the collective compressibility of the E-cadherin-GFP overexpressing HRasV12-mutants (Supplementary Fig. 8a). Indeed, collective compressibility of these mutants was now rescued to the range of wildtype population (Fig. 4f) and thus explains the rescue in compressive stress when these mutants encounter wildtype cells in their vicinity.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this work, we combined experimental investigation at the very initial stages of carcinogenesis and in silico modeling to define the mechanistic and mechanical basis for EDAC. We discovered a pre-elimination compressive stress, which is unique to the cell competition underlying EDAC and henceforth, may be called as competition-induced compressive stress (CICS). We also characterized the putative biophysical properties responsible for CICS to show that higher preferred homoeostatic area and compromised cell-cell junctions are distinct properties that the transformed cells acquire upon HRasV12-expression. On the other hand, the growth rate difference between the competing populations, which is classically considered to be the driver of cell competition and oncogenesis, did not appear to be a critical factor for EDAC against HRasV12-expressing mutant cells. Further, to reconcile these observations in a single framework, we utilized computational SPV model to show that a collective compressibility differential might explain the emergence of CICS during EDAC. While the existing tools to quantitate collective compressibility are either too complex, too customized to be implemented, or rely entirely on the impending cellular strength to suspend freely, we developed an inexpensive, physiologically compatible technique called gel compression microscopy. GCM includes a compliant substrate for monolayer adhesion, whose stiffness can be modulated, and real-time measurements of collective compressibility can be performed. Using GCM, we showed that the mutant cell population is indeed more compliant to in-plane compression. GCM measurements thus revealed an oncogenic transformation in the epithelial cells leading to a multicellular length-scale change in its material property. Taken together, we present a mechanical picture of EDAC where the oncogenic transformation of a group of cells in an otherwise normal epithelium modulates their cellular biophysical properties making them more compressible as a collective. Subsequently, a local compressive stress emerges, which leads to a successful defence against cancer.

In this regard, a recent study has parameterized differences in cellular-scale measurements during cell competition between wildtype and mutant cells lacking a tumor suppressor protein, Scribble42. They have used an agent-based model to show that the homeostatic density of the competing cell types primarily governs mechanical cell competition, while the local tissue organization influences the outcome and kinetics of biochemical competition42. However, a direct measurement of forces has remained missing. In contrast, we used stress microscopy techniques to discover CICS and trying to understand the mechanistic origin of CICS led to the discovery of differential compressibility. Hence, our study elucidated how individual cell mechanics integrate at the multi-cell scale to bring about oncogenic cell elimination through EDAC. Together, it is tempting to speculate that the transformed cells struggle to achieve their desired, higher cellular area while being resisted by the surrounding normal cells, giving rise to CICS.

In the context of stable epithelial monolayers, it is shown that factors that trigger cell competition, including Ras family of proteins, Myc, Toll and apicobasal polarity proteins are also involved in modulating junctional tension8,43-45. Consistent with these observations, we demonstrate that junctional fidelity in HRasV12-expressing mutant cells is aberrant. The most important epithelial cell-cell adhesion protein, E-cadherin, loses its junctional localization upon oncogenic transformation. The membrane-anchored E-cadherin molecules get actively displaced from the junctions of the mutant cells and trafficked through cytoplasm and not turned over back to the junctions in time, compromising junctional stability. This instability is corroborated by the diffused cytoplasmic occurrence of another protein associated with cell-cell junctional maturation protein, alpha-catenin. Remarkably, just by enriching the overall pool of available E-cadherin in the mutants, there was significant recovery in their collective compressibility and the CICS disappeared.

In the paradigm of EDAC, what still remains to be explored is the cellular phenotypes which fundamentally perturb the bulk mechanical elasticity of epithelial cells as they undergo transformation. How changes in cellular morpho-mechanical landscape rewire EDAC, to push it either towards pro-tumorigenic or anti-tumorigenic fate, is an interesting but enigmatic area of work impending investigation. Furthermore, how cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous cell biological features arise in normal as well as transformed mutant cells to guide mechanobiological patterns of cell competition, remains poorly understood. Finally, it will be interesting to investigate whether the compressive stress also appears on EDAC against mutations in other Ras family proteins and whether the underlying mechanism can be generalized beyond EDAC against HRasV12-expressing mutant cells. Nevertheless, using a physiologically model system, our comprehensive study has unveiled the previously enigmatic physical principle and molecular mechanism that underlie cell competition in epithelial tissue’s defense against cancer. This breakthrough not only provides crucial insights into the fundamental dynamics of this process but also opens exciting avenues for the emerging field of mechano-medicine. By understanding how mechanical forces and cell compressibility play a pivotal role in cell competition, we have set the stage for innovative therapeutic strategies that leverage these principles to target and potentially mitigate the spread of cancerous cells within tissues.

We also acknowledge the intramural funds at Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Hyderabad from the Department of Atomic Energy Energy, India (under Project Identification No. RTI 4007) and the generous funding by the Human Frontier Science Program (HFSP, grant no. RGP0007/2022). This work was also supported in part by National Science Foundation grant DMR-2046683, the Center for Theoretical Biological Physics grant PHY-2019745 and funding from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, to D.B.

fn.p: D.B. and T.D. supervised the project. P.G., S.P.P., and P.D. performed the experiments. S.K. and D.B. formulated the theoretical model, performed the computer simulations, and analyzed the simulation results. P.G., S.P.P., and T.D. analyzed the experimental results. H.K.S. contributed to the development of Gel Compression Microscopy. P.G., S.K., S.P.P., D.B., and T.D. wrote the manuscript. All authors edited and approved the manuscript.
The authors declare no competing interests.

element-citation.article-title: Outcompeting cancer
Is cell competition relevant to cancer?

caption.title: Competition induced compression of HRasV12 mutant population.
caption.p: a, Heterogenous competing population constituted by wildtype and HRasV12 mutant cells (40:1 number ratio) cultured on a 4 kPa polyacrylamide gel. Induction with doxycycline (dox) shows progressive GFP-HRasV12 expression and concomitantly, the mutant cells round up to finally extrude out of the monolayer (mutant colony is marked by blue dotted circle), hpi-hours post induction. b, Traction force microscopy generated map of the forces exerted by MDCK cells during competition between mutant and wildtype cells (mutant colony is marked by red dotted circle), analysis done post 2 hours of dox induction. c, Stress microscopy generated mean normal stress map depicting compressive stress at the mutant loci (marked by red dotted circle) during competition between wildtype and mutant cells, analysis done post 2 hours of induction with dox. Bayesian force inference generated d, interfacial tension map, e, relative intracellular pressure map during cell competition between wildtype and mutant cells (mutant colony marked by black dotted circle), inference performed post 2 hours induction with dox. f, Normalized relative intracellular pressure characterized with Bayesian force inference, plotted from a pool of 3 independent experiments, analysis performed post 2 hours induction with dox. Data are mean±sd. Statistical significance was calculated using Unpaired t-test with Welch’s correction. Scale bar, 50 µm for all experimental panels. g, The junctional tension at the edges shared by cells in a circular island of mutant (M) cells (which constitute 12% of the total number of cells in a randomly generated ensemble, with the island’s diameter being approximately 40% of the length of the box) is significantly lower than that of their surrounding wild-type (WT) counterparts. This is due to the single-cell parameters of the M cells, which include KAM=0.7,A0M=0.8,P0M=3.8, which corresponds to a shape index of q0M=P0M/A0M=4.25 in contrast to the WT cells with parameters KAWT=1.0,A0WT=1.0,P0WT=3.65 (i. e. q0WT=3.65). As a result, the M colony exhibits lower edge tension and is less rigid than its surrounding WT cells. h, The average pressure in the M island (with the same spatial distribution as shown in Fig. 1g and coarse-grained over 50 ensembles of initial configurations) is elevated, with single-cell parameters of KAM=0.7,A0M=1.5,P0M=3.8. In contrast, the WT cells have the same single-cell parameters as in Fig. 1g. i, The relative compaction level, denoted by Δρ = A0/Ā − 1, of the M population is a function of the average pressure (Π) and depends on an array of cell area elasticity ratios, k=KAM/KAWT. In the M island, an increase in the value of Π is driven by an increase in A0M. j, The linear-response compressibility, denoted by C=∂Δρ∂Π, for M and WT cells as a function of k.

caption.title: Gel Compression Microscopy reveals a differential collective compressibility between wildtype and transformed mutants.
caption.p: Conceptual representation depicting the a, basis and functionality, and b, the data acquisition as done when performing Gel Compression Microscopy (GCM). Micropatterned PDMS mould (shown in blue) with a 150 µm polyacrylamide (PAA) gel (shown in teal) casting donut shaped cavity, is mounted on the glass in a 35mm glass bottom dish. pH-responsive gel (shown in yellow) is casted as a slab in the centre of the donut shaped PAA gel. Cells of interest are cultured on top of the collagen-I coated PAA gel of defined stiffness. During GCM, the pH-responsive gel expands radially outwards and compresses the cells-PAA gel interface in turn, which is imaged in live (depicted by the imaging region of interest (ROI)) c, Representative image panels for 4 kPa PAA gel control, MDCK-wildtype (WT) cell monolayer or MDCK-HRasV12 mutant cells cultured on 4 kPa PAA gels for GCM. Pre-compression ROIs are shown to depict PAA gel alone or cells-PAA gel interface (marked by yellow dotted lines) as well as their respective Post-compression ROIs representing the respective interfaces after 90 mins of continuous compression (marked by white dotted lines), Scale bar, 50 µm. d, Creep analysis where compressive strain (as fraction to the pre-compression perpendicular shift of the interface) incurred during GCM is plotted as a function of the corresponding time of compression in minutes, Data are mean±sd from three independent experiments. e, Analytical representation depicting the methodology and equations used to quantitate compressive strain and relative compressibility (relative to the respective PAA gel alone control). f, Relative compressibility measurement based on e, shows a distinct and lower value for MDCK-WT population whereas MDCK-MT population shows no distinction compared to the PAA gel case. Data are mean±sem from three-four independent experiments. Statistical significance was calculated using Unpaired t-test with Welch’s correction. g, Representative image panels for 0.87 kPa PAA gel control, MDCK-WT cell monolayer or MDCK-MT cells cultured on 0.87 kPa PAA gels for GCM. Pre-compression ROIs are shown to depict PAA gel alone or cells-PAA gel interface (marked by yellow dotted lines) as well as their respective Post-compression ROIs representing the respective interfaces after 90 mins of continuous compression (marked by white dotted lines), Scale bar, 50 µm. h, Relative compressibility measurement based on e, shows a distinct and lower value for MDCK-WT population as also seen in f. Importantly, MDCK-MT population shows a distinctly lower value compared to the PAA gel alone case but higher than the MDCK-WT case. Data are mean±sem from three-four independent experiments. Statistical significance was calculated using Unpaired t-test with Welch’s correction.

caption.title: Theoretical modelling reveals different regimes of mechanical phenotypes in cell competition.
caption.p: In the computational simulations, we assessed both the bulk and shear moduli of the cell colonies. The bulk modulus provided insights into a tissue’s mechanical response to isotropic compression, while the shear modulus was essential for evaluating the tissue’s reaction to shear forces. These mechanical properties were analysed for a wide range of parameters k, A0M and δq0. Here, k encoded competition in cell area elasticities between the cell types. When k < 1, the mutant colony was more compressible than the WT cells that surrounded them. On the other hand, δq0 encoded the competition in cellular junctional properties; when δq0 > 0, the mutant cells had weakened cellular junctions compared to the WT cells. a, Behavior of the differential bulk modulus ΔB between WT and M cells in the k − δq0 plane for A0M=A0WT=1. The black dotted line corresponds to ΔB = 0. b, ΔB plotted as a function of k A0M for a range of δq0 values. The inset shows ΔB − b δq0 as a function of k A0M for the same data. Here we used b = 1.7 ± 0.2 . c, The behavior of the differential colony tension Δτ in the k − δq0 plane for AM = 1. The white dotted line corresponds to Δτ = 0. d, Δτ plotted as a function of δq0 for a range of k values (and A0M=1). The inset shows ΔτMk2 as a function of δq0 exhibiting a scaling collapse. Here we find d = 0.53 ± 0.12 . Both the scaling parameters in Fig. 3b and Fig. 3d are obtained by minimizing error functions which we defined to measure the closeness of the respective data sets. e, Based on the analysis of Fig. 3(a-d), we predict a phase diagram which qualitatively distinguishes between mechanical phenotypes that are favored in non-proliferative mechanical cell competition. Specifically, a colony of cells with lower δq0 and higher k AM will have a competitive advantage, as they exhibit lower compressibility and higher rigidity. The predicted phase diagram serves as a useful tool for identifying such mechanical phenotypes.

caption.title: Compromised E-cadherin based cell-cell junctions in the HRasV12 transformed mutants underlie competition induced compressive stress as well as rescued collective compressibility.
caption.p: a, Representative image panels to show immunostained MDCK-wildtype (WT) or MDCK-HRasV12 mutant (MT) cells for E-cadherin extracellular domain marked by DECMA-1. The immunostaining is performed a, WITH detergent (TritonX-100) or b, WITHOUT detergent to demonstrate the inherent instability in MT-MT junctions but not WT-WT junctions whereas the extracellular domain being intact in either case. Scale bar, 10 µm. c, E-cadherin live dynamics are studied in MDCK-WT or -MT cells mildly overexpressing E-cadherin-GFP. Representative differential interference contrast (DIC) and E-cadherin-GFP image panels are shown. Temporal dynamics for each cell-type is shown as a colour projection map where each time stamp is differentially coloured in the ‘yellow hot’ colour panel and superimposed. Each time frame refers to 5 second imaging window. Scale bar, 5 µm. d, Super-resolution spinning-disk confocal microscopy using optical photon reassignment (SoRa) image panels to show endogenous E-cadherin in MDCK-WT, -MT or -MT overexpressing E-cadherin-GFP. Junctional E-cadherin is shown in insets from the three scenarios to depict E-cadherin loss in mutant cells and rescue in mutant cells overexpressing exogenous E-cadherin-GFP. Scale bar, 10 µm for all image panels and 2 µm for all insets. e, Traction force microscopy and stress microscopy panels for cell competition between MDCK-WT cells and MDCK-MT cells overexpressing E-cadherin-GFP. Competition induced compressive stress as seen in Fig. 1c, is evidently rescued when E-cadherin is supplied exogenously in the mutant cells. Scale bar, 10 µm. f, Relative compressibility measurement based on Fig. 2e, shows a distinct and lower value for MDCK-WT population whereas MDCK-MT population shows no distinction compared to the PAA gel control, as also seen in Fig. 2f. Importantly, MDCK-MT cells overexpressing E-cadherin-GFP show a distinctly similar value to the MDCK-WT case, showcasing genetic rescue to the mechanical phenotype of compressibility differential. Data are mean±sem from three-four independent experiments. Statistical significance was calculated using Unpaired t-test with Welch’s correction.
